query: What is the metaphoric meaning of silo?
claim_cluster: ['A functional silo exists when the business processes of a functional unit within the division of labor of an organization focus inwardly on their functional objectives.', 'BPR recommends the removal of a function-focused approach and its replacement with a process-focused approach, thereby destroying the functional silos and encouraging cross-functional integration.', 'Something to do with fermenting seems to be missing in these explanations', "the origin of the metaphor is the idea that grain silos don't communicate with each other", "This becomes problematic when the direction of focus creates barriers that do not serve a reasonable business purpose and negatively impacts the unit's ability to serve their role in the broader mission of the organization.", 'it is a rather strange metaphor for isolation', 'A term used within business process re-engineering (BPR) to denote areas within an organization where managers occupy a privileged position in terms of resources and influence, and where they use this for their own, self-interested, functionally-oriented motives rather than for the wider benefit of the business.', 'Silo is a metaphor', 'Process-oriented organizations break down the barriers of structural departments', 'A functional group or department within an organization acts as a silo or island in its lack of interaction with other groups and in not sharing its internal data or processes', 'There are people and groups in an organization that behave in the same way as silos', 'Process-oriented organizations try to avoid functional silos', "It's a fermenting over time, away from the rest of the influences", 'Poorly operated silos become structurally unsound and can lead to a collapse or worse', 'A functional silo in an organization or business is not inherently negative', 'silo is being used as a metaphor here, not an actual silo']
ground: [[], ['managers occupy a privileged position in terms of resources and influence, and use this for their own, self-interested, functionally-oriented motives rather than for the wider benefit of the business'], [], ["grain silos don't communicate with each other"], [], ['the metaphor is for isolation'], [], ['A grain elevator is a collection of bins', 'Every bin could have a unique product and once a product is there it just sits', 'It should have no interaction with any other silo', 'The other silos can be emptied shipped refilled with new product, etc.', 'It does not affect the silo in question'], [], ['My study manual for the course put it as this'], ['Their little piece of the world does not interact with the rest of the organization', 'They make decisions without consideration of how they affect the rest of the business', 'They have (and work to maintain) barriers to groups around them', 'Typically they are perceived as being less interested in the overall success of the organization than to maintaining their normal state'], [], [], [], ['A functional silo in an organization or business has a very positive place'], ['According to the Oxford Dictionary, there is a literal meaning of silo: a tower or pit on a farm used to store grain', 'a pit or other airtight structure in which green crops are compressed and stored as silage', 'there is also the metaphorical meaning: a system, process, department, etc. that operates in isolation from others']]

claim_ground_kps:
{
  "claim": "Difference between -ing nouns and real nouns",
  "ground": [
    "Gerunds (-ing nouns) have both verbal and noun properties, can take articles, adjectives, plural endings, and function as objects or subjects, but often refer to the process or action itself; real nouns like those ending in -ment refer to the result or product of the action. (positive, nuanced)",
    "'A developing' as a standalone noun sounds awkward or unnatural in some contexts. (negative)",
    "'An understanding' is a valid example of an -ing noun used as a real noun, showing some -ing forms are accepted as nouns. (positive)",
    "Not all verbs have corresponding -ing nouns, and the relationship is not universal. (neutral)",
    "'A hanging' demonstrates that some -ing forms have become established as nouns with specific meanings. (positive)",
    "'Driving' in 'his dangerous driving' shows -ing nouns can describe actions or behaviors, often with a negative or critical tone. (negative)",
    "'Developing' can also function as an adjective, not just a noun, indicating flexibility but also potential confusion. (neutral)"
  ]
}
query: What's the difference between an -ing noun and a real noun
claim_cluster: ['It is OK to use developing as a noun', 'Its substantival nature is shown by its ability to take an attributive adjective.', 'In general, you can generate a noun that refers to the process of the verb', 'These should be used at the appropriate situations.', '"developing" is not a noun.', "Even if you can generate an -ing noun from a verb, there's no reason to assume it would mean the same thing as a noun ending with -ment generated from the same verb", "An '-ing' can be added to create a new noun", 'A gerund would normally have in it the verbal nature which the corresponding noun does not have.', 'Its substantival nature is shown by its ability to take a definite or an indefinite article.', 'In the case of "developing" one might compare "The development of AIDS in Africa has proved to be one of the biggest tragedies in the Third World" vs "The new president aims at developing the country\'s poor-relief system".', 'Many verbs have many corresponding nouns', "The noun form of verbs by adding '-ing' are called gerunds.", "It's not a universal rule", 'Development is a noun', 'If development refers to a single major development such as a shopping mall, then developing is not possible', 'You cannot say, I am going for a swimming.', 'Some verbs have corresponding nouns', 'Its verbal nature is shown by the fact that it can have a subject.', 'You cannot use any word anywhere you feel like, while writing in English.', 'Its substantival nature is shown by its ability to be the object of a preposition.', "If they always meant the same thing, we wouldn't need different suffixes", 'Developing is also a noun', 'Develop is a verb', 'You have to say, Swimming is his hobby.', 'Developing is the gerund form of the verb develop', 'In parallel cases a noun ending in -ment would normally imply the result of an action, the product of an action while the corresponding gerund would refer to the action itself.', 'Its substantival nature is shown by the fact that it can take a plural ending.', 'You can definitely say, I am going for a swim.', "When do I use gerunds and not the 'normal noun' form? query: What use is the sniper rifle in Mass Effect 3?
claim_cluster: ["Once you get the Black Widow 1 you'll probably be killing anything without major defenses in one shot", 'It makes thin cover almost irrelevant with AP Ammo/Pierce Mod/Javelin/Widow/B.Widow', 'Time dilation on Soldiers and Infiltrator make sniping a viable option, especially against heavily-armored enemies.', 'You will want a sniper rifle to deal with an Atlas', 'Infiltrators get additional benefits for Sniper Rifles', 'The extra damage a sniper does comes in handy if you can headshot a humanoid foe', 'The slowed time allows you to take headshots easier', 'Infiltrators can use Tactical Cloak to position themselves strategically to take out opponents from long ranges, and line up a perfect shot unnoticed.', 'A powerful sniper rifle with a high rate of fire and the time dilation effect makes you almost unstoppable', 'Tactical Cloak also allows you to take your time to get a good headshot while dealing extra damage to boot', 'Sniper Rifles are still quite good, even at fairly short ranges.', 'Snipers like the Widow and Javelin are tremendously powerful', 'Snipers really do a ridiculous amount of damage if statted properly', "If you're an Infiltrator or Soldier you get a 'time dilation' effect with the sniper rifle which slows down time", 'Soldiers can use Sniper Rifles to open an engagement, as well as shooting from the hip with them to get a little bit of extra punch against armored opponents.']

query: How do inversions of extended chords work?
claim_cluster: ['One just gets more inversions', 'Open voicings use whatever notes are appropriate, but will not use every consecutive note from that chord', '13th chords are usually in root position because their inversions are academic.', 'All voicings are subject to root or inversions', 'Seventh chords can put any chord tone into the bass including the seventh', '9th chords almost always have the 9th above the root', 'C, C/E, C/G, C/B♭ (call it C7/B♭ if you like) are commonplace.', "For clarity's sake put the extensions above the root", 'Every voicing will also have a label for its inversion, but an inversion tells us little about the voicing', 'In practice, notes are usually omitted from extended chords to avoid jarring dissonances, so not all of the inversions are seen in the wild.', "Whilst being closely related, they're not the same, although they do both contribute to information about a chord, they are not synonymous", "Order of other notes (or even lack of them) won't affect the naming of that inversion", 'Inverting a 13th chord has the effect of turning it into a different 13th chord.', "Anything beyond the 7th in a 'pile-of-thirds' type extended chord is almost always going to be in the upper structure, not as the bass note.", 'The conventional treatment would be to place the extensions above the chord root', "If you're thinking in guitar terms, and there's a bass player, there may be little point in thinking of 'inversions' in what you play, just 'voicings'.", 'They can double or treble certain notes', 'The inversion will establish the lowest note on a chord', 'Inversion of chords does not specify the disposition of upper voices (in general)', 'In theory, inverting an extended chord works the same as inverting a simple triad, except that more inversions are possible.', "In certain circumstances, 3rd, 4th, 5th inversions won't necessarily sound good", 'Closed voicings occur when each and every note is as close to the next (up and down) that it can be', "A chord's voicing is a more complete picture that would include the inversion as well as other characteristics.", 'Inversions (and root position) will tell what note is at the bottom', "A chord's inversion will only tell you which note is in the bass.", 'Putting the extensions in the bass can give the impression of other chords with some added non-chord tones or their own extensions', 'The term voicing is often used in the context of a particular instrument, e.g. piano voicings or guitar voicings, and therefore include a consideration of what is idiomatic for that instrument.', "It     'In American English, "to skin a cat" can also refer to a gymnastic move, but this is unrelated to the proverb’s meaning (neutral, clarification).',
    'The earliest printed citation of the exact phrase is from Seba Smith’s 1840 story, confirming its use in American literature (positive, documentary evidence).',
    'Some sources suggest the phrase may refer to the literal act of skinning cats, but this is debated and not central to its meaning (neutral, historical ambiguity).',
    'The phrase is used metaphorically in literature to illustrate multiple approaches to a problem, reinforcing its figurative sense (positive, metaphorical use).',
    'The phrase may have originated in the Mississippi river region, possibly referring to catfish preparation, but this is one of several theories (neutral, regional origin).',
    'A 1709 sermon contains a similar phrase, showing the idea predates the current wording (positive, early usage).',
    'Authors from the 19th century treated the phrase as a well-known proverb, indicating its established status (positive, cultural recognition).',
    'Earlier variants of the phrase exist, showing its evolution over time (positive, linguistic evolution).',
    'The phrase’s many versions and wide distribution suggest it is a general proverb adapted to local contexts (positive, widespread acceptance).',
    'The phrase may have been inspired by the process of removing animal skins, but its meaning is figurative (neutral, possible origin).',
    'The phrase appears in 19th-century periodicals, confirming its common usage (positive, print evidence).',
    'Multiple sources cite Seba Smith’s 1840 story as the earliest printed example, supporting its American literary roots (positive, historical documentation).'
  ]
}

query: Serial to USB converter
claim_cluster: ['If a computer does something like send a single character, and wait for the peripheral to respond before sending the next, then the character rate is determined by the latency for two entire usb packets - one to send a single character, and one to receive one.', 'With legacy systems, you may get lucky and find it works fine, it may work but slowly, or it may not work reliably at all.', "In today's world where USB-serial converters are as or more common than real serial ports, it's important to design protocols so that you can send out a lot of data, before needing to wait for a reply.", 'If you try to move a lot of data in tiny pieces with USB, you lose - badly.', 'Other protocols which depend on constant back-and-forth of short messages or single characters between a computer and a serial peripheral can slow to a crawl (or even mis-operate) when used with a usb-serial converter.', 'USB is inherently packet-oriented, with comparably high-latency.', 'Classic serial ports are ordinarily byte-oriented, ie, one character at a time with quite low latency.', 'Anything (hardware or even client software) designed to use a serial port should be tested for usability with usb-serial converters early enough in its development that the design can be changed to fix any issues discovered.', "USB is great for moving a lot of data at once, but it's actually slower at moving tiny amounts of data.", 'For just typing on a terminal program talking to a modem or an embedded device, or even uploading files, etc, this is really not a problem, because single doses of the latency are small in human terms, and the USB can easily move blocks of data fast enough keep up with any serial baud rate.', 'My own previous simple win32 management tool for that device ran without apparent delay on the same laptop with the same converter.', "A piece of management software for an embedded device which had been written and tested by a contractor using a real serial port turned out to use some variation of .NET serial calls that turned out to be 'watch the results crawl in' slow on a laptop with a usb-serial converter."]

query: Zergling late-game strategies and uses
claim_cluster: ['Late-game, zerglings are most commonly used in conjunction with ultralisks.', 'This will allow Zerglings to get into melee and inflict lots of damage very quickly', 'A drop of 20+ cracklings into the enemy main or an expo can do massive damage to their base very quickly if their army is not nearby to stop it immediately', 'I have had great effect sending zerglings in as a second wave', 'Zerglings are useful to build if you have minerals to spare but no gas', 'Zerglings can stay a main part of a regular army composition by using mutas and zerglings to abuse their mobility advantage if the game is rather spread out across the map', 'Zerglings should generally be moved in as a flanking maneuver after your army engages', 'zerglings are too weak to be useful at all against a mature defense network', "Combining zerglings with a defiler's dark swarm can make them particularly effective vs terran", 'It is much better to use zerglings early game and tech up if you are not incredible at micro', 'You can get a number of uses out of zerglings late game', 'Zerglings can still be used to try to get surrounds on enemy armies', 'If you Dark Swarm Terran with a Defiler their biggest disadvantage (easily killed) is nullified while under the Dark Swarm', 'Keeping a batch of zerglings hidden to sweep into an undefended base when he goes to attack you is a brilliant strategy that can throw off your opponent', 'Because Zerglings are so cheap, you can consume the Zerglings with the Defiler for more energy which you can use to throw out more Dark Swarms', 'The Adrenal Gland upgrade is very powerful', 'Late game zerglings are a risky manoeuvre depending on your APM', 'It is better to have some extra zerglings rather than floating the money', 'If he breaks off his attack, you can simply let the zerglings die dealing a lot of damage to his economy, or go off and hide again', 'Zerglings are fairly useless against an army with reavers or archons']

query: Is "rotate" in "Earth rotates around the sun" the correct word?
claim_cluster: ['I would use orbit to refer to the motion around the sun', "'Orbit' is more proper", 'The distinction between rotate and revolve may as well be public knowledge.', 'Earth rotates around the sun', "There is no problem with 'the Earth rotates around the Sun' on its own", 'I would use rotation or revolution to refer to the spin', 'Confusion creeps in if you also want to refer to how the Earth is spinning around its own axis', 'The distinction between rotate and revolve is taught to all students.', "The 'rotates around the sun'/'rotation around the sun' pair is much less common in published writing than either 'revolves around the sun'/'revolution around the sun' or 'orbits the sun'/'orbit around the sun.'", 'The Earth orbits around the Sun', 'rotate is an acceptable word in that context', 'words such as orbit or revolve should be used instead', 'I would mark the misuse in people older than 6th graders.', 'This has been a sort of litmus test in the scientific community for a long time.', '"Rotate" is fine, for plain English or scientist', 'The Earth rotates around its poles', "I disagree with the choice of the word 'rotate'", "There is no reason to prefer the 'rotates'/'rotation' wording when describing a planet that is proceeding on its elliptical circuit around a star."]
ground: [[], ["'Orbit' denotes angular motion of the line joining the axes of the Earth and the Sun around the axis of the Sun"], ['The distinction between rotate and revolve is taught to all students.', 'Objective 2a in the 6th grade education standard is to identify the difference between the motion of an object rotating on its axis and an object revolving in orbit.'], [], [], [], [], ['Objective 2a in the 6th grade education standard is to identify the difference between the motion of an object rotating on its axis and an object revolving in orbit.'], ["From these charts, it appears that the 'rotates around the sun'/'rotation around the sun' pair is much less common in published writing than either 'revolves around the sun'/'revolution around the sun' or 'orbits the sun'/'orbit around the sun.'"], [], [], [], ['The distinction between rotate and revolve is taught to all students.', 'Objective 2a in the 6th grade education standard is to identify the difference between the motion of an object rotating on its axis and an object revolving in orbit.'], ['The distinction between rotate and revolve is taught to all students.', 'Objective 2a in the 6th grade education standard is to identify the difference between the motion of an object rotating on its axis and an object revolving in orbit.'], ['the subject is not the detail of the elliptical trajectory'], [], ["'Rotate' is most properly used to describe angular motion around the Earth's own axis"], ["Taking into account this strong preference in written usage, I can't think of any reason to prefer the 'rotates'/'rotation' wording when describing a planet that is proceeding on its elliptical circuit around a star."]]

query: "To be subject to" vs. "to be subjected to"

query: Is there a way to get the awesome robe enchantments on armor?
claim_cluster: ['armor is more effective the more health it has to protect', 'Even a minor enchant on gloves as opposed to no gloves would help immensely', 'Not wearing armor makes me incredibly vulnerable to melee attacks', 'You can do the alchemy/enchanting loop and get good enchants on various items to equal or surpass the archmage robe or grand master robe', 'One can decide between not wasting 6 skill points and being OP enough anyways, or get the 6 skill points in enchanter 1-5 and Insightful Enchanter and enchant some non-armor gloves with up to +70 Magicka', 'making your way to 100 enchanting and picking the Extra Effect perk would let you apply the Magicka Regen and Fortify School enchantments to a single piece, allowing both to scale normally', "With the above equipment, you'd wind up +44% (or +144%) more magicka regen, -69% (or -94%) less fortify school, and +70% magicka and almost no armor rating", 'The real benefits to armor become clear the more you have', 'You are able to finally enchant your own gear that surpasses the Archmage Robes', 'spending more level-ups on health is a simpler solution to survival', 'Together, you will have -100% Magicka cost and all spells will cast for free', 'With Extra Effect, you could add both to a helmet, armor and ring, and fortify school to a necklace, which brings you to +216% magicka regen and +116% fortify school, on your choice of apparel', 'the greater the fortify, the less the cost on your spells', "Regen Magicka's base magnitude is 20% and Fortify School's is 8%, so that means at best you should be able to add about 72% magicka regen or 29% fortify school to a single enchantment on one piece of equipment", 'One should probably wear the Ring of Recovery', 'the less the cost on your spells, the less need for regen', 'You can enchant non-armor gloves easily', 'You could level up enchanting, use a potion, and do fortify (school) on chest, head, ring, necklace and that school can be free', 'It is a balancing factor to keep wizards wearing robes instead of home-made heavy armour', 'The maximum magnitude (100 enchant, the appropriate perks, +32% Fortify Enchanting Potion) is: skill multiplier = 1 + 0.3 * ((132 - 10) / 100) ^ 2 = 1.4465; net magnitude = base magnitude * 1 * 1.4465 * 2 * 1.25 = base magnitude * 3.6163', 'If you can put two enchantments on one item you could have two free schools of magic', "the Fortify School and Magicka Regen enchantment's 2nd effect, the Magicka Regen, will always remain limited to 10%", "The best stuff you can find would be something like the following: Head: Morokei - +100% magicka regen (note that you would have to replace this for Mage Armor perks to work); Ring: Ring of Peerless [School] - +25% fortify [school] - or - Ring of Recovery - +100% magicka regen; Chest: Master Robes of [School] - +150% magicka regen, +22% fortify [school]; Neck: Necklace of Peerless Magicka - +70 magicka (AFAICT necklaces can be enchanted with Fortify [School] but generally aren't found as such)", 'The formula for enchanting apparel is net magnitude = base magnitude * soul multiplier * skill multiplier * (1 + Enchanter perk) * (1 + specific perk modifier)', "The enchantments don't work so well on armor", 'The enchanting options for gloves are not that expansive', 'You should always be moving and not getting hit at all with melee', 'The enchanting options for gloves do exist']
ground: [[], ['Even if you do not excel in enchanting'], ['I often get one-hit killed'], ['If you cheat'], ['there are NO enchanted non-armor gloves in the game'], [], ["With the above equipment, you'd wind up +44% (or +144%) more magicka regen, -69% (or -94%) less fortify school, and +70% magicka and almost no armor rating"], ['Each additional point in armor adds more to physical durability than the previous point'], ['with enchanting at 100'], [], ['With high enough Enchantment, you can create four items that give -25% Magicka cost'], ['With Extra Effect, you could add both to a helmet, armor and ring, and fortify school to a necklace'], [], ["Regen Magicka's base magnitude is 20%", "Fortify School's is 8%"], ['Ring of Recovery gives +100% magicka regen', 'one has an empty gloves slot'], [], ['There is no enchanted non-armor gloves in the game'], ['leveling up enchanting, using a potion, and fortifying (school) on chest, head, ring, necklace can make that school free'], ["You can't get Enchantment high enough to create those +150% robes"], ['skill multiplier = 1 + 0.3 * ((132 - 10) / 100) ^ 2 = 1.4465', 'net magnitude = base magnitude * 1 * 1.4465 * 2 * 1.25 = base magnitude * 3.6163'], ['putting two enchantments on one item allows for two free schools of magic'], ['Fortify starts at 5%, and goes up with skill / perks'], [], ['skill multiplier = 1 + 0.3 * ((skill - 10) / 100) ^ 2'], ['I have the enchantments'], [], ['as a mage around level 30 you can cast ironflesh which gives 80 armor', 'with mage armor 2 around that level it increases it to 200 armor'], []]

query: What is the conversion for dotted quarters to bpm in 6/8 time?
claim_cluster: ['6/8 does not change anything aside from the meter', 'Dotted quarter=72 IS 72 beats per minute', 'That equates to two clicks per bar, each click meaning three quavers', 'one plays the piece with 72 dotted quarters per minute or 216 eighth notes per minute', 'You would set a metronome to 72 (adagio) because this will click on the beats', 'You would not find a metronome clicking every 2/3 of the musical beat very helpful', 'You would count as 1-trip-let 2-trip-let :| or something similar emphasising the beats (numbers) only', 'The time signature 6/8 is compound duple', "It's good to train yourself to be able to make the change without changing the metronome marking.", 'Dotted-quarter=72 equates mathematically to 8th=216 (3X72) or quarter=108 (half of 216)', "It's manic", 'As you are playing, it may sometimes feel like two groups of three beats in a measure, and sometimes like two beats per measure.', "The 6/8 won't affect the tempo to play at", 'Set for 72bpm and recognise two clicks per bar', 'I want to know if 6/8 changes anything', 'In a 6/8 meter, you can either think of the eighth notes as the beat, in which case there will be six of them in a measure; or you can think of the dotted quarter as the beat, in which case there will be two of them in the measure.', 'If the tempo is given as a dotted crotchet = 72, this means there are 72 beats per minute, and (3x72=) 216 pulses per minute', 'If you set the metronome to three times that - 216bpm, it would be six clicks per bar - one for each quaver, were there six played in a particular bar', 'It would be 72 bpm', 'I have a piece that is set at dotted quarter=72 in 6/8 time', "I think it's best to be flexible about this, and realize that there is a duality."]

query: Word for something that's always reliable, but never the best?
claim_cluster: ['"competent" is acceptable and satisfactory, though not outstanding', "The Oxford Dictionary has 'A person or thing ready to be deployed immediately, especially if needed as backup in an emergency' as a definition for standby", 'Journeyman is suitable for a person', "If used without other adjectives, the implication is that the person or thing's reliability is its most important feature", "A 'Jack of all trades' can be relied on to do many different things", "Most Americans will automatically fill in 'but master of none', meaning that he does not do an excellent job in any of those things", "The adjective trusty is a good word to describe something that's maybe not necessarily the best of its kind, but you know that it's reliable because you've used it for so long that you can rely on it", 'A standby is reliable', 'Quite often a standby was in use but replaced, but is still good for the job', 'A workhorse describes a person (or sometimes an object) that dependably performs a task', 'If a standby were the best, it would actually be in use', "The Cambridge Dictionary has 'standby noun something that is always ready for use, especially if a regular one fails' as a definition for standby", "In basketball and other sports, a 'role player' can be relied on to do his job consistently well, but not at the level of a 'star' or 'superstar'", 'Something can be a standby when it is ready for use', "Words like 'dependable' and 'reliable' already (within certain contexts) euphemistically express the meaning that it wasn't the best/first choice", "The word 'Journeyman' is often used to describe an individual who is reliable but not the best in their chosen profession", 'Most things that are perfect for a particular task have other adjectives that are more likely to be used if they are applicable']
